Udon Shin Review | Bon Appetit

So long, ramen. See ya, soba.FacebookPinterestTwitterEmailPhoto by Xavier Girard LachaîneGO HERE: for the last udon you will ever need. Maybe you haven't thought of udon, always overlooked for sexy ramen or faithful soba, as something you could love. But at Shin, that squiggly, chewy noodle that you’ve only eaten as an afterthought is better than any other you’ve slurped. How did you ever ignore such beauty before? And will you ever know this kind of love again?ORDER THE: zaru udon—cold noodles served with a dipping sauce—for the purest experience. Or get the niku udon, with thinly sliced beef and  a soft poached egg in savory broth, for a warming option on a chilly night. But if you want to feel decadent, get the carbonara-inspired bowl that comes topped with butter, pepper, Parmesan, and a big slice of bacon tempura (that’s right: bacon that's been battered, fried, and taken to a new level of crispiness).THE VIBE IS: intimate, to say the least. Shin is not much more than a sliver of a shop, with only a short counter and a couple of small tables. While you might want this interlude to last, remember that this is still a Tokyo noodle shop and you were once one of those people waiting in line outside. Don’t linger too long because everyone else needs a taste too.PRACTICAL STUFF: Open Sunday to Thursday from 11 a.m to 11 p.m., and Friday and Saturday from 11 a.m. to midnight. Closed during the New Year’s holiday. The menu is available in Korean and English, and the staff only speaks limited English. The nearest subway station is Shinjuku.Photo by Xavier Girard LachaîneUdon in the making.
